BC-INTERNET-TALENT-AGENT-1125(2TAKES)-NYT 
AGENT'S ROLE IN MUSIC SITE CHANGES WAR OVER RIGHTS 

   By MATT RICHTEL   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   Michael Ovitz, superagent and former Disney president, has made
his name _ and a considerable fortune _ aggressively securing
hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties and other payments for
artists and studios that he represents. But his latest endeavor, a
pop-culture hub on the World Wide Web, has the potential to drain
income from some of those same clients by enabling users of the
site to copy music, media and other files from one another.

   Last year, Ovitz and a business partner bought 51 percent of
Scour.com, an entertainment site and search engine used to find
music and movie files. Last month, though, the site added a
feature, Scour Exchange, that lets users exchange multimedia files
online with one another, including copyrighted material by some of
the world's leading artists, some of them clients of Ovitz's talent
management agency, Artists Management Group.

   The involvement of Ovitz in Scour.com would seem to be at cross
purposes with his role in Artists Management. But his backing of
Scour.com also marks a significant shift in the roiling battle over
copyright protection in the digital age.

   Until now, the archnemeses of the recording industry have been
20-something entrepreneurs creating Web sites that make it easy to
exchange copyrighted files over the Internet.

   Ovitz's backing for Scour.com's file-exchange mechanism suggests
that opposition may be eroding to technology that, by many
accounts, will force the development of new business models for the
entertainment industry, changing how artists are compensated for
their work and how their work is protected.

   Ovitz declined to comment. But James Ellis, general counsel for
Artists Management Group and a director of Scour Inc., said it
makes more sense to embrace the technology than to fight it. ``In
the face of a rapidly changing marketplace, Scour had to respond,
to maintain and grow its audience and give them what they wanted,''
he said.

   Ellis said that Scour hoped to find ways to make file sharing
lucrative for artists. And he said Scour was vigilant about kicking
copyright infringers off the site if Scour was informed of the
problem.

   Dan Rodrigues, 24, co-founder and president of Scour.com, said
Scour Exchange could not be held accountable if some people used
the service to pirate copyrighted material. ``It's impossible for
us to screen, censor or review,'' he said. ``It's not our job to
know what is, or is not, infringing.''

   The Scour.com Web site does include a copyright notice but,
practically speaking, it is simple to obtain copyrighted material
by entering the search term for the desired song or movie.

   Some Internet music industry analysts say Ovitz has a
potentially serious conflict of interest in holding a stake in
Scour.com and managing artists whose music and movies may be traded
freely on Scour Exchange. The works of several of the artists
represented by Ovitz's agency are exchanged on Scour Exchange,
including music from the group Blues Traveler and the singer Liz
Phair.

   ``There is a significant potential for conflict,'' said Kevin
Hause, an Internet music analyst with IDG, a market research group.
``He is someone entrusted to look out for the best interest of
artists.''

   But Rodrigues said that Ovitz is actually building a bridge
between the old-world media companies and the new business models
of the Internet. ``He understands both sides of the equation,''
Rodrigues said. ``He understands what entertainment companies need
and what's important to copyright holders and what works on the
Web.''

   Scour.com was founded in a two-bedroom apartment near the campus
of the University of California at Los Angeles. Traffic to the site
grew quickly, and the company eventually attracted the interest of
Ovitz, who read about Scour.com in the school newspaper, and the
grocery billionaire Ron Burkle. For $4 million, the pair took a
majority stake in the business, said Rodrigues.

   The company reached deals with a number of Internet start-ups
and media companies to provide content to include with the search
function. Scour is now contemplating a variety of business models,
including taking advertisements, selling subscriptions and selling
multimedia content.

   It now features movie trailers and music promotions provided
legitimately by movie and record companies, along with some items
for sale, like music available for download. The site now receives
2 million visitors each month.

   As with Napster, the controversial site offering a service that
lets users share and trade their music files online, users of Scour
download software over the Internet that allows them to store and
catalog multimedia files on their own computers.

   Scour Exchange posts those catalogs and then enables users of
the service to visit one another's computers over the Internet and
share and download one another's music, movies, and other holdings.
The service does not provide the content, but facilitates the
exchange.

   Napster, based in San Mateo, Calif., has been sued by the
Recording Industry Association of America for reportedly
facilitating music piracy in a pending case that many expect to set
a precedent. The association and the five major record labels it
represents say its artists are losing tens of millions of dollars a
year because of rampant music piracy on the Internet, a practice
that the trade group says threatens to undermine the very economics
of the creation of music.

   Hilary Rosen, the president of the recording industry
association, said the group was aware of Scour Exchange's
activities and was considering its options. But she said the
organization did not want to rush to file lawsuits against each
Napster-like service, hoping the decision in that case case might
dissuade copycats. ``We don't have any interest in litigating our
way through the Internet,'' she said.

   But in reality the industry association might simply lack the
resources to file enough lawsuits, given the boom in these services
and the complexity of the attendant technology. Most recently, a
23-year-old Irish programmer created Freenet, which would enable
people to share files online directly with one another in a way
that would make it virtually impossible for copyright holders to
find a central database or hub to blame for the interaction.

   Therein lies a key argument of Rodrigues and Scour Exchange.
They contend that the free exchange of files online may be
inevitable, so media companies might as well get on board. ``Were
trying to work with entertainment companies to help them use it,''
Rodrigues said, adding, ``Ovitz has been instrumental to us in
leveraging entertainment relationships he has.''

   Scour has some agreements with other companies aimed at helping
users to download multimedia files in a way that protects
copyright. For instance, Liquid Audio, a company that makes
technology to enable digital distribution of music in a way that
protects copyright and that is a partner of some of the major
record labels has a deal with Scour to enable it to sell several
encrypted songs on the site.

   Andrea Cook Fleming, vice president of marketing for Liquid
Audio, said Liquid Audio is providing an alternative to people who
might otherwise pirate music rather than pay for it.

   Another company that has signed a deal with Scour is Nettwerk
Productions, an independent record label aiming to promote one of
its up-and-coming artists, a musician named Brian Transeau who
records as BT, on Scour.

   Cathy Barrett, director of strategic marketing for Nettwerk,
said the deal puts the label in an awkward position because the
site is promoting the music of BT, but with a single click of the
mouse, users can get pirated versions of BT's songs free through
Scour.

   But BT said people will inevitably trade copyrighted music on
the Web, so artists might as well try to figure out how to
capitalize on the sites making that possible. ``It's an
uncontrollable situation,'' BT said. ``You might as well embrace it
and make the best of it, or you're going to go insane trying to
prevent it.''

   Still, some musicians and their agents disagree. Howard King, a
Los Angeles attorney who is representing Metallica and Dr. Dre in
lawsuits against Napster, said that Ovitz and Scour have an
obligation to stand up to piracy. ``Just because some kid in the
Philippines knows how to create a devastating virus, doesn't mean
we say, `Oh it'll happen again,' and not do something about it,''
he said.
